justification: The Method section states that participants "completed the 15-item Mindful Attention and Awareness Scale (MAAS)", identifying MAAS as the instrument used to assess trait mindfulness.
The article notes that mindfulness facets—including Observing—were assessed with the "39-item Five Facet Mindfulness Questionnaire (FFMQ, Baer et al., 2006)."
The Describe facet is one of the five assessed by the "39-item Five Facet Mindfulness Questionnaire (FFMQ)."
Acting with Awareness is listed among the five facets measured via the "Five Facet Mindfulness Questionnaire (FFMQ)."
construct: Acting with Awareness facet of mindfulness

justification: Non-reactivity is explicitly identified as one of the FFMQ facets administered to participants.
Non-judging appears as one of the five dimensions captured by the administered FFMQ.
The Measures list includes the "11-item Experiences Questionnaire" which is described as the assessment instrument for decentering.
Participants completed the "10-item version of the Perceived Stress Scale (PSS, Cohen & Williamson, 1988)," designating it as the stress measure.
The paper reports use of the "16-item Penn State Worry Questionnaire (PSWQ)" as the instrument for assessing worry/anxiety.

measured_by: Center for Epidemiological Studies Depression Scale Revised (CESD-R)
justification: Depression symptoms were captured with the "20-item Center for Epidemiological Studies Depression Scale Revised (CESD-R)."
The text cites the "Self-reported Inappropriate Negotiation Strategies Scale (SINS, Ruedy & Schweitzer, 2010)" as the tool for measuring willingness to use unethical negotiation tactics.

The authors hypothesized that "perceptual accuracy (measured through a temporal judgment task) would be positively related to the Observing facet," making the temporal judgment task the operational measure of perceptual accuracy.
They state that "cognitive control (measured through a Stroop task) would interact with scores on the Non-reactivity facet," identifying the Stroop task as the measure of cognitive control.
During Procedure, participants "completed three insight problems (Schooler et al., 1993)," which served as the assessment of insight-based problem solving.
Participants also "completed two non-insight problems (Schooler, Ohlsson, & Brooks, 1993)," providing the measure for analytic/non-insight problem-solving ability.
